thread.title: Fever take WNBA Finals Game 1 behind big game from January
thread.title_full: Fever take WNBA Finals Game 1 behind big game from January

title: Fever take WNBA Finals Game 1 behind big game from January
text:
Indiana Fever guard Briann January (20) shoots in the first quarter against Minnesota Lynx forward Maya Moore (23) at Target Center. (Photo: Brad Rempel-USA TODAY Sports)
Story Highlights Game 2: Fever at Lynx, 8 p.m. Tuesday, ESPN2 482 CONNECT 16 TWEET LINKEDIN 4 COMMENT EMAIL MORE MINNEAPOLIS – While others in the Target Center were losing their heads, Briann January kept hers.
The 11,023 fans, most waving towels, grew loudest in the third quarter when the Minnesota Lynx trimmed a seven-point deficit to four. January responded with one jump shot, then another, to extend the Indiana Fever’s lead to eight as the arena grew silent.
In the fourth quarter, as the clock neared the two-minute mark, January split the defense for a lay-in. Soon thereafter, she added yet another jumper to push the Fever ahead by five.
The Fever secured a 75-69 victory Sunday, giving them a 1-0 lead in the best-of-five WNBA Finals. It was a showcase for January, a perennial all-defensive team selection who scored a season-high 19 points.
INDIANAPOLIS STAR
How the Fever were built, player by player
“She’s the key to that team,” Lynx coach Cheryl Reeve said. “I know everybody is talking about (Tamika) Catchings, and that’s true. But when you have a point guard that’s getting things done at that level – she scored 19 and had us twisted – that says a lot about her.”
The Lynx are 18-2 under Reeves in the playoffs, and both losses were to the Fever in Game 1s of WNBA Finals. The Lynx will try to even the series Tuesday (ESPN2, 8 p.m.).
Game 3 will be Friday and Game 4 (if necessary) next Sunday, both at Indianapolis.
January started 0-of-5 from the field but finished 6-of-14. She was 6-of-6 on free throws and added four rebounds and six assists.
One moment in which she lost her cool was when she fouled out with 1:12 left. She was restrained by teammates but assessed a technical. January said Maya Moore “jumped out of bounds” like pro wrestler Hulk Hogan, inducing the call from official Sue Blauch. January pointed to a bleeding cut on her face that she said came from the collision.
Facebook Twitter Google+ LinkedIn Gallery | Fever vs. Lynx, Game 1 of WNBA Finals Fullscreen Post to Facebook Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed.

Brad Rempel-USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen Indiana Fever forward Tamika Catchings (24) blocks the shot of Minnesota Lynx forward Maya Moore (23) in the first quarter at Target Center. Brad Rempel-USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen Minnesota Lynx forward Maya Moore (23) dribbles in the first quarter against Indiana Fever guard Marissa Coleman (25) at Target Center. Brad Rempel-USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen Indiana Fever guard Briann January (20) shoots in the first quarter against Minnesota Lynx guard Lindsay Whalen (13) at Target Center. Brad Rempel-USA TODAY Sports Fullscreen Like this topic? You may also like these photo galleries: Replay Autoplay Show Thumbnails Show Captions Last Slide Next Slide “At the same time, I need to keep my composure,” January said. “Apparently, something I did, you know, caused her to call a technical.”
Moore made the technical free throw and 1-of-2 thereafter, cutting the Fever’s lead to 70-67. Shavonte Zellous drove to the rim for a layup to make it 72-67 with 53 seconds left, and Catchings scored the final three points on free throws.
Catchings said she challenged January to lead the Fever on both ends of the floor.
“When she plays the way that she knows how to defensively, she gets under people’s skin so bad,” Catchings said. “It’s fun to watch as a teammate. Even offensively, down the stretch, it’s the best I have seen her play, to be able to finish out games, I think, ever.
“The confidence she played with tonight, we need her to play with that for the rest of the series.”
INDIANAPOLIS STAR
5 things to watch in WNBA Finals
Moore scored 27 points and 6-6 center Sylvia Fowles 21, but no other Lynx player had more than nine. January’s primary defensive assignment was Seimone Augustus, one of Minnesota’s five Olympic gold medalists. Augustus shot 3-of-11 for nine points in 35 minutes.
Reeve was vexed afterward because the Lynx led the Fever in shooting percentage (42 to 36 percent), rebounds (34-32) and free throw attempts (23-16).
“How do you lose that game?” she said, then answered her own question. “We just didn’t do the little things at key times, and they did. This is Indiana. This is what they do.”
The Fever were 16-of-16 on free throws and outscored the Lynx 22-12 in second-chance points.
The Lynx missed an opportunity to seize control early. The Fever shot 1-of-9 with three turnovers midway through the first quarter.
The score was tied at 10 after one quarter -- the lowest-scoring quarter in finals history -- and the Fever closed out the second quarter on a 16-5 run, forging a 35-29 lead. The Lynx led just once in the second half, 62-61, before Marissa Coleman’s 3-pointer returned the advantage to the Fever.
Coleman scored 16 points, Catchings 12, and Zellous and Shenise Johnson 10 each.
The collective nature of the Fever was epitomized on the final play of the half. Catchings stole the ball and passed to Coleman, who in turn passed to Johnson. Erlana Larkins scored at the buzzer off Johnson’s assist.
The Fever coach, Stephanie White, is new, as are most of the players. But so far, the Fever are following the same old formula from their 2012 championship: Fall behind 1-0 in each of the first two best-of-three series, then win Game 1 of the finals.
“I think our team, we just believe in one another,” White said. “We trust one another. We understand that no matter what happens in the course of the game, if we come together, we’re going to put ourselves in position to win.”
Call Star reporter David Woods at (317) 444-6195. Follow him on Twitter: @DavidWoods007.
